Posts.Content: A little learning is a dangerous thing; Drink deep, or taste not the Pierian spring. There shallow draughts intoxicate the brain And drinking largely sobers us again. - Alexander Pope, 1709 Im a 67-yo retired technical writer whos never had a serious illness. My high PSA score and subsequent biopsy and diagnosis came at me straight out of the blue. And yet, February of this year seems like a century ago. Ive been reading books on the subject. (Recommended: You Can Beat Prostate Cancer by Robert J. Marckini.) Watching documentaries. Scanning this forum (which is great). Corresponding with survivors. And yet after two months of saturation in the subject matter I feel like Im at the very beginning. So many aspects of prostate cancer are amorphous, even arbitrary. (Example: determining stage number or Gleason score. Sometimes I wonder if the pathologists are flipping coins.) Categorical consensus about diagnosis, treatment, and even whether one is cured is impossible to find. There seems to be no source of reliable information we can all draw from. (Maybe NCI?) But there are numerous marketing sites attempting to disguise themselves as such. It seems that everyone involved with this disease, from patients to care providers to treatment developers, has a stake in the process. And yes, some patients too have a stake in the sense that once committed to an avenue of treatment they take ownership of it and tend to proselytize about how superior their treatment is, even to the point of downplaying side effects and other negative aspects. But perhaps the least able to determine next steps in the journey around this disease is the one who must make the call: the new patient, me. Im here in this forum (and only this forum) to ask my fellow sufferers for their take on the decisions Ive made so far and those Im in the process of making. Treatment has not yet begun so I can change my mind if I want to. I consider myself supremely fortunate at my age (67) to come in at Stage 2, and thus I have plenty of options. My priorities are (1) eradication of the cancer; (2) freedom from a return of the cancer; (3) freedom from urinary incontinence; and (4) reduction or elimination of other side effects. My reading so far has prejudiced me against surgery. You know the reasons why so I wont go into them. The best chance of a successful outcome with minimal side effects seems to be radiation, and thats the way Im headed. According to my radiation oncologist, a course of his clinic's state-of-the-art IMRT should give me an 85 percent chance of a complete cure. My radiation oncologist's specialty is brachytherapy and he recommended that procedure first, followed by IMRT. My response was, since brachytherapy carries its own risks and side effects, and IMRT on its own has an such an overwhelming success rate, Id rather skip the brachytherapy and still be confident of a good outcome. And here is my first question to the forum . . . QUESTION: Should I start with a course of brachytherapy, or bet all my marbles on IMRT? And then there's proton beam. Many sources Ive read are almost stridently enthusiastic about proton beam therapy. But my healthcare provider doesnt have it. They have a recent IMRT system and say it is just as good. Ive found a couple of limited but legitimate comparisons of the two technologies, and one of them cites substantially higher risk of urinary incontinence from proton beam. Both studies say the jury is still out on proton beams superiority or even equivalence to IMRT with regard to prostate cancer. (The only consensus is no consensus.) So Im not sold on proton beam. And if I were Id be in for a fight with my insurer to pay out-of-network treatment costs. Id have to stay in a different city (Seattle or San Diego  Loma Linda has aged out, apparently) for two months at my expense. And before any of that, Id have to wait my turn in the line-up for limited proton beam resources. All this would take months, and Im afraid of my prostate malignancy spreading outside the gland during that interval. What would you do? QUESTION: Should I go expend a lot of time and dollars to get proton beam, or will IMRT suffice for my needs? And then theres the question of hormones. Ive got a rare autoimmune condition called hypophysitis that has shut down my pituitary gland and thus nearly all my hormone production, including testosterone and growth hormone. Ive been taking supplements of those hormones for nearly five years now. My doctors recommend I discontinue them during my IMRT treatment. I will do so, though grudgingly, because only guys whove been without these hormones will be able to fully relate to how empty life can be in their absence, how difficult it is to engage with work and other pursuits, what little pleasure is left in what were once the most life-fulfilling experiences. What the hell, I can do without them for eight or nine weeks. But what about afterward? QUESTION: Has anyone in this forum been counseled to avoid testosterone even after theyve been cured of their prostate cancer? My current path, as said above, is IMRT only, beginning in the next 10 days or so. (I have found some great information in this forums What I need to know about external beam radiation treatments thread. Thanks!) Im wondering if the radiation will eradicate my prostate, or if it will have any functionality afterward. Is my quality of life going to take a major downturn? What are the odds of being struck again by prostate cancer, only this time by a more aggressive version? And most haunting of all, what if IMRT fails to kill all the cancer cells. Can I reboot and opt for a course of brachytherapy, or are all options but chemo no longer valid? So much to learn, so little time to decide. Even if its just a few words about the way youd go, Id love to hear them. And so in advance I thank all in the forum who have read this and especially those who can provide me the wisdom of their experience.

AgeInfo.Phrase: Alexander Pope  1709 Im a 67 yo retired technical writer whos
supremely fortunate at my age  67  to come in at Stage

Posts.Signature: 67-yo retired technical writer, active cyclist, healthy lifestyle Interests: reading, sport cycling, British cars, little dogs Favorite recent book: "How We Die" by Sherwin B. Nuland, MD Favorite recent documentary: "Cancer: The Emperor of All Maladies" from PBS February 2017 annual checkup PSA 14.7; previous PSA 2 years previous was 3.9 Biopsy showed 5 of 12 samples infected across the gland Gleason 3+3, 4+3, 3+4, 3+4, 3+3 Pelvic CT and full body bone scan were clear Diagnosis Stage 2 prostate cancer, confined to the gland May 2017 with radiation oncologist decided to use IMRT to eliminate the malignancy

And if I were Id be in for a fight with my insurer to pay out-of-network treatment costs. Id have to stay in a different city (Seattle or San Diego  Loma Linda has aged out, apparently) for two months at my expense. And before any of that, Id have to wait my turn in the line-up for limited proton beam resources. All this would take months, and Im afraid of my prostate malignancy spreading outside the gland during that interval. What would you do? QUESTION: Should I go expend a lot of time and dollars to get proton beam, or will IMRT suffice for my needs? And then theres the question of hormones. Ive got a rare autoimmune condition called hypophysitis that has shut down my pituitary gland and thus nearly all my hormone production, including testosterone and growth hormone. Ive been taking supplements of those hormones for nearly five years now. My doctors recommend I discontinue them during my IMRT treatment. I will do so, though grudgingly, because only guys whove been without these hormones will be able to fully relate to how empty life can be in their absence, how difficult it is to engage with work and other pursuits, what little pleasure is left in what were once the most life-fulfilling experiences. What the hell, I can do without them for eight or nine weeks. But what about afterward? QUESTION: Has anyone in this forum been counseled to avoid testosterone even after theyve been cured of their prostate cancer? My current path, as said above, is IMRT only, beginning in the next 10 days or so. (I have found some great information in this forums What I need to know about external beam radiation treatments thread. Thanks!) Im wondering if the radiation will eradicate my prostate, or if it will have any functionality afterward. Is my quality of life going to take a major downturn? What are the odds of being struck again by prostate cancer, only this time by a more aggressive version? And most haunting of all, what if IMRT fails to kill all the cancer cells. Can I reboot and opt for a course of brachytherapy, or are all options but chemo no longer valid? So much to learn, so little time to decide. Even if its just a few words about the way youd go, Id love to hear them. And so in advance I thank all in the forum who have read this and especially those who can provide me the wisdom of their experience.

Nuland, MD Favorite recent documentary: "Cancer: The Emperor of All Maladies" from PBS February 2017 annual checkup PSA 14.7; previous PSA 2 years previous was 3.9 Biopsy showed 5 of 12 samples infected across the gland Gleason 3+3, 4+3, 3+4, 3+4, 3+3 Pelvic CT and full body bone scan were clear Diagnosis Stage 2 prostate cancer, confined to the gland May 2017 with radiation oncologist decided to use IMRT to eliminate the malignancy
Posts.Title: A little learning is a dangerous thing . . .

Posts.Content: A little learning is a dangerous thing; Drink deep, or taste not the Pierian spring. There shallow draughts intoxicate the brain And drinking largely sobers us again. - Alexander Pope, 1709 Im a 67-yo retired technical writer whos never had a serious illness. My high PSA score and subsequent biopsy and diagnosis came at me straight out of the blue. And yet, February of this year seems like a century ago. Ive been reading books on the subject. (Recommended: You Can Beat Prostate Cancer by Robert J. Marckini.) Watching documentaries. Scanning this forum (which is great). Corresponding with survivors. And yet after two months of saturation in the subject matter I feel like Im at the very beginning. So many aspects of prostate cancer are amorphous, even arbitrary. (Example: determining stage number or Gleason score. Sometimes I wonder if the pathologists are flipping coins.) Categorical consensus about diagnosis, treatment, and even whether one is cured is impossible to find. There seems to be no source of reliable information we can all draw from. (Maybe NCI?) But there are numerous marketing sites attempting to disguise themselves as such. It seems that everyone involved with this disease, from patients to care providers to treatment developers, has a stake in the process. And yes, some patients too have a stake in the sense that once committed to an avenue of treatment they take ownership of it and tend to proselytize about how superior their treatment is, even to the point of downplaying side effects and other negative aspects. But perhaps the least able to determine next steps in the journey around this disease is the one who must make the call: the new patient, me. Im here in this forum (and only this forum) to ask my fellow sufferers for their take on the decisions Ive made so far and those Im in the process of making. Treatment has not yet begun so I can change my mind if I want to. I consider myself supremely fortunate at my age (67) to come in at Stage 2, and thus I have plenty of options. My priorities are (1) eradication of the cancer; (2) freedom from a return of the cancer; (3) freedom from urinary incontinence; and (4) reduction or elimination of other side effects. My reading so far has prejudiced me against surgery. You know the reasons why so I wont go into them. The best chance of a successful outcome with minimal side effects seems to be radiation, and thats the way Im headed. According to my radiation oncologist, a course of his clinic's state-of-the-art IMRT should give me an 85 percent chance of a complete cure. My radiation oncologist's specialty is brachytherapy and he recommended that procedure first, followed by IMRT. My response was, since brachytherapy carries its own risks and side effects, and IMRT on its own has an such an overwhelming success rate, Id rather skip the brachytherapy and still be confident of a good outcome. And here is my first question to the forum . . . QUESTION: Should I start with a course of brachytherapy, or bet all my marbles on IMRT? And then there's proton beam. Many sources Ive read are almost stridently enthusiastic about proton beam therapy. But my healthcare provider doesnt have it. They have a recent IMRT system and say it is just as good. Ive found a couple of limited but legitimate comparisons of the two technologies, and one of them cites substantially higher risk of urinary incontinence from proton beam. Both studies say the jury is still out on proton beams superiority or even equivalence to IMRT with regard to prostate cancer. (The only consensus is no consensus.) So Im not sold on proton beam. And if I were Id be in for a fight with my insurer to pay out-of-network treatment costs. Id have to stay in a different city (Seattle or San Diego  Loma Linda has aged out, apparently) for two months at my expense. And before any of that, Id have to wait my turn in the line-up for limited proton beam resources. All this would take months, and Im afraid of my prostate malignancy spreading outside the gland during that interval. What would you do? QUESTION: Should I go expend a lot of time and dollars to get proton beam, or will IMRT suffice for my needs? And then theres the question of hormones. Ive got a rare autoimmune condition called hypophysitis that has shut down my pituitary gland and thus nearly all my hormone production, including testosterone and growth hormone. Ive been taking supplements of those hormones for nearly five years now. My doctors recommend I discontinue them during my IMRT treatment. I will do so, though grudgingly, because only guys whove been without these hormones will be able to fully relate to how empty life can be in their absence, how difficult it is to engage with work and other pursuits, what little pleasure is left in what were once the most life-fulfilling experiences. What the hell, I can do without them for eight or nine weeks. But what about afterward? QUESTION: Has anyone in this forum been counseled to avoid testosterone even after theyve been cured of their prostate cancer? My current path, as said above, is IMRT only, beginning in the next 10 days or so. (I have found some great information in this forums What I need to know about external beam radiation treatments thread. Thanks!) Im wondering if the radiation will eradicate my prostate, or if it will have any functionality afterward. Is my quality of life going to take a major downturn? What are the odds of being struck again by prostate cancer, only this time by a more aggressive version? And most haunting of all, what if IMRT fails to kill all the cancer cells. Can I reboot and opt for a course of brachytherapy, or are all options but chemo no longer valid? So much to learn, so little time to decide. Even if its just a few words about the way youd go, Id love to hear them. And so in advance I thank all in the forum who have read this and especially those who can provide me the wisdom of their experience.

AgeInfo.Phrase: Alexander Pope  1709 Im a 67 yo retired technical writer whos
supremely fortunate at my age  67  to come in at Stage

Posts.Signature: 67-yo retired technical writer, active cyclist, healthy lifestyle Interests: reading, sport cycling, British cars, little dogs Favorite recent book: "How We Die" by Sherwin B. Nuland, MD Favorite recent documentary: "Cancer: The Emperor of All Maladies" from PBS February 2017 annual checkup PSA 14.7; previous PSA 2 years previous was 3.9 Biopsy showed 5 of 12 samples infected across the gland Gleason 3+3, 4+3, 3+4, 3+4, 3+3 Pelvic CT and full body bone scan were clear Diagnosis Stage 2 prostate cancer, confined to the gland May 2017 with radiation oncologist decided to use IMRT to eliminate the malignancy

Id have to stay in a different city (Seattle or San Diego  Loma Linda has aged out, apparently) for two months at my expense. And before any of that, Id have to wait my turn in the line-up for limited proton beam resources. All this would take months, and Im afraid of my prostate malignancy spreading outside the gland during that interval. What would you do? QUESTION: Should I go expend a lot of time and dollars to get proton beam, or will IMRT suffice for my needs? And then theres the question of hormones. Ive got a rare autoimmune condition called hypophysitis that has shut down my pituitary gland and thus nearly all my hormone production, including testosterone and growth hormone. Ive been taking supplements of those hormones for nearly five years now. My doctors recommend I discontinue them during my IMRT treatment. I will do so, though grudgingly, because only guys whove been without these hormones will be able to fully relate to how empty life can be in their absence, how difficult it is to engage with work and other pursuits, what little pleasure is left in what were once the most life-fulfilling experiences. What the hell, I can do without them for eight or nine weeks. But what about afterward? QUESTION: Has anyone in this forum been counseled to avoid testosterone even after theyve been cured of their prostate cancer? My current path, as said above, is IMRT only, beginning in the next 10 days or so. (I have found some great information in this forums What I need to know about external beam radiation treatments thread. Thanks!) Im wondering if the radiation will eradicate my prostate, or if it will have any functionality afterward. Is my quality of life going to take a major downturn? What are the odds of being struck again by prostate cancer, only this time by a more aggressive version? And most haunting of all, what if IMRT fails to kill all the cancer cells. Can I reboot and opt for a course of brachytherapy, or are all options but chemo no longer valid? So much to learn, so little time to decide. Even if its just a few words about the way youd go, Id love to hear them. And so in advance I thank all in the forum who have read this and especially those who can provide me the wisdom of their experience.

supremely fortunate at my age  67  to come in at Stage

Posts.Signature: 67-yo retired technical writer, active cyclist, healthy lifestyle Interests: reading, sport cycling, British cars, little dogs Favorite recent book: "How We Die" by Sherwin B. Nuland, MD Favorite recent documentary: "Cancer: The Emperor of All Maladies" from PBS February 2017 annual checkup PSA 14.7; previous PSA 2 years previous was 3.9 Biopsy showed 5 of 12 samples infected across the gland Gleason 3+3, 4+3, 3+4, 3+4, 3+3 Pelvic CT and full body bone scan were clear Diagnosis Stage 2 prostate cancer, confined to the gland May 2017 with radiation oncologist decided to use IMRT to eliminate the malignancy
Posts.Title: A little learning is a dangerous thing . . .

Age.Phrase: Alexander Pope  1709 Im a 67 yo retired technical writer whos

DoctorRecommended.Sample: According to my radiation oncologist, a course of his clinic's state-of-the-art IMRT should give me an 85 percent chance of a complete cure. My radiation oncologist's specialty is brachytherapy and he recommended that procedure first, followed by IMRT....Ive been taking supplements of those hormones for nearly five years now. My doctors recommend I discontinue them during my IMRT treatment....My radiation oncologist's specialty is brachytherapy and he recommended that procedure first, followed by IMRT. My response was, since brachytherapy carries its own risks and side effects, and IMRT on its own has an such an overwhelming success rate, Id rather skip the brachytherapy and still be confident of a good outcome....My doctors recommend I discontinue them during my IMRT treatment. I will do so, though grudgingly, because only guys whove been without these hormones will be able to fully relate to how empty life can be in their absence, how difficult it is to engage with work and other pursuits, what little pleasure is left in what were once the most life-fulfilling experiences....
